SAMUEL JEFFRY . I know the prisoner, and have witnessed his conduct—he is very inoffensive, but of weak mind, an does not know what he is about.
NOT GUILTY .

1525.
JOHN SPENCE,
WILLIAM SWAIN and
THOMAS JOHN
SON were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
John Roche Williams, from his person; and that Swain and Johnson had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN ROCHE WILLIAMS . I am a boot-closer, and live in Hampstead-road. On the evening of the 24th of May I was at Greenwich-fair—the officer spoke to me, and I found my handkerchief was gone—I had seen it safe about an hour before—this now produced is it.
Swain. Q. What do you swear to it by? A. By the holes in it—there are about four holes—I won't swear to it exactly.
COURT. Q. Was your handkerchief like this in every respect? A. Yes, exactly the same pattern.

MICHAEL HAYDON (City police-constable, No. 274.) On the 24th of May, about seven o'clock in the evening, I saw the three prisoners walking together for about a quarter of an hour, at Greenwich fair—I then saw Spence take a handkerchief from Mr. Williams's pocket and pass it to Swain—Johnson was behind, covering them—as soon as he did it they ran away together behind some booths—I told the prosecutor, and then went after the pri
soners—they were all three together—I took them—I had seen them watching people's pockets as they were walking up and down the fair.

Swain. Q. Did you see me with these two prisoners? A. Yes—I found the handkerchief on you—I suppose I was a couple of yards from you when the handkerchief was taken—you went behind the booths the moment it was taken.
JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 180.) I found this handkerchief on Swain—two other handkerchiefs were found on Johnson.
Johnson. They were what I fetch my food in; I was only discharged from prison the Saturday before.
Spence. I saw Swain buy this handkerchief.

Swain's Defence. I was discharged from the county prison on the Saturday, and on Whit-Monday I went to the fair with a young man; I happened to miss him, and I met with this lad Johnson; he asked me whether I would stand some beer; I took him into a public-house and stood a pot of beer; a young man came in with a handkerchief and asked me whether I would buy it; he wanted 1s. 6d. for it, and I gave it him; I was coming out of the public-house, the constable saw me, and knowing me by giving me six months at another pri
son, he took me, and asked me whether I had the handkerchief; another officer said he watched me, and I was by myself; I was with a sailor.

MICHAEL HAYDON
re-examined I had been Swain by himself about three hours before.

Johnson's Defence I was discharged from prison on the Saturday before; I was trying to get an honest living when the officer came and took me; Swaine said he was going to have a pot of beer, and he would give me some.

MICHAEL HAYDON
re-examined I produce a certificate of Swain's former conviction at this court—(read—Convicted 23rd Nov, 1846, confined six months)—the prisoner Swain is the person.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (City police-constable, No. 122.) I produce a certifi
cate of the prisoner Johnson's former conviction—(read—Convicted 23rd Nov. 1846, confired six months)—the prisoner is the person.

SPENCE—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Months.

SWAIN—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

1526.
WILLIAM FANCIS was indicted
for stealing 2 boots, value 6s. 6d., the goods of
James Cooper; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY Aged 31.—
Confined One Year.

1527.
CHARLES PEMBURY was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 2l. 10s., and 1 watch-chain, 1d.; the goods of
Thomas Davis and that he had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS DAVIS I live in Sun-alley, Woolwich, and am a sawyer. On 26th of May, about eight o'clock in the morning, I went into the White Lion public-house—the prisoner was there in the parlour—I took my watch out of my pocket to wind it up—the prisoner said he would take it to the bar, and have it put to rights for me—I said, "No, let it alone; I shall put it to rights myself"—he took it out of my hand, and went off with it.

Prisoner. He gave it into my hand, and told me to go and pawn it. Witness No, I did not—he did not bring anything back for it—I was not the worse for liquor—I have known him ever since he was born—I thought he might bring it back.

GEORGE BARTON . I am in the employ of Mr. Carter, a pawnbroker, at Greenwich. On the 26th of May the prisoner came, and brought this watch—he pawned it for 12s., in the name of Thomas Smith—he said it was his own.

JOHN GRIFFIN (police-constable R 229.) I apprehended the prisoner on the 3rd of June—I told him he was charged with stealing a watch from the prosecutor—he replied that he had settled matters with the prosecutor—I said I should take him to the station, and I asked what he had done with the watch—he said he had pawned it at Greenwich, and had lost the duplicate—he did not tell me at what shop he pawned it.
JOHN WALKER (police-constable R 298.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at Maidstone—(read—Convicted 9th March, 1846, and confined six months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY Aged 28.—
Confined One Year.

1528.
JAMES COOK was indicted
for stealing 4 bushels of oats, value 15s.; and 1 sack, 2s., the goods of
Henry Dunkin, in a barge on the navi
gable river Thames.

DANIEL DAVIS . I live in Two Kings-row, Horsleydown, and am a watch-man in the employ of Messrs. Courage and Donaldson. On the evening of the 20th of April, about nine o'clock, I was in the neighbourhood of Horsley-down-stairs—the prosecutor, Mr. Dunkin, had two or three barges lying of there—I met the prisoner and James Bennett, who has been convicted—Bennett had a sack of oats, and the prisoner had an empty sack under his arm, and a hat, which I believe was Bennett's—(Bennett had no hat on)—the prisoner was in front—I stopped Bennett—the prisoner turned back, and asked what I had to do with Bennett, and held up his fist to me—I called out, "Police"—the prisoner dropped his empty bag, and ran away—the sack that Bennett had, contained oats.

DAVID DAVIS . I am in the employ of Courage and Donaldson. I heard the cry of "Police" that night—I saw the prisoner and Bennett—the pri
soner walked first, with a hat in his hand and a sack under his arm—Davis caught hold of Bennett, and the prisoner went off when they hallooed out for a policeman, and left his bag behind him.
Prisoner. Q. Which arm did I have the sack under? A. I do not know—you had it under your arm, and dropped it—I let you pass me near the Rose and Crown.

GEORGE TERRY . I am in the employ of Mr. Henry Dunkin, a corn
dealer and lightman. He had some barges at Davis's-wharf, Horsleydown—there were eighty sacks of oats in one barge—at nine o'clock that night I received information, and missed one sack of oats—this is it—it had the same kind of oats in it that was in the barge; I had left the barge about half an hour.

Prisoner's Defence I had nothing to do with it; I was at Horsleydown, and came up the stairs; I heard Davis speak; I turned to see what it was, and he had hold of Bennett; I walked back; a man came and said, "Cook, I must have you;" I said, "I have done nothing;" I went away.
NOT GUILTY .

1529.
JAMES HARLEY was indicted
for stealing 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 half-sovereign, 1 sixpence, and 3 pence; the property of
William Payne; from his person.

WILLIAM PAYNE . I am lodging at Mr. Harris', in Point-street, Ports
mouth—on the 12th of May I was on Wimbledon Common, on my way to Portsmouth—I was near some trees—the prisoner came up to me with ano
ther man, who asked me if I was on the road—I said "No," I was standing there because it was raining—the prisoner then asked me if I wanted to buy a razor—I said no, I did not know that I did, what sort was it—he took it out of his pocket and showed it to me—I was going to buy it—I took a small bag out of my pocket which contained a half
sovereign, a sixpence, and three pence in copper—I was going to get the threepence out of the bag, and the prisoner caught the bag out of my hand—I was going to catch him, and the other man said if I touched him he would give me some cold steel—they went off for thirty or forty yards, then ran as hard as they could—I stood under the trees till they were out of sight, and then pulled off my smock-frock and followed them—I got sight of them a long way a-head, and followed them for five or six miles—when the prisoner got to Kingston he went into a baker's shop—I followed behind a cart and passed the shop—I then saw him come out of the shop and come up towards London again—I gave information to an officer, who took him—I can swear he is the man that took my bag.

THOMAS HOLLOWAY (police-constable V 226.) On the 12th of May Payne gave me information—I proceeded in pursuit of the prisoner, and saw him at the corner of Coomb's-lane—I asked him whether he had not offered a razor for sale, and while I was speaking to him the prosecutor came up and said, "That is the man that robbed me"—the prisoner said, "I have not got the money, the other man has got it"—I took the prisoner to the station—I found nothing on him—this is the razor Payne gave me, which he said he had of the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1530.
ARTHUR LEARY and
THOMAS WYATT were indicted for
unlawfully receiving from
Edward Ransby the sum of 2s. 6d., under pretence of helping him to recover part of the sum of 197l. 10s., the amount of an order stolen from him by
John Jenner, (see page 417,) they not having caused Jenner to be brought to trial for the said felony.

EDWARD RANSBY . I live at Bawsey, in Suffolk. On Monday, the 26th of April, I was in town—I went to the Yorkshire Stingo, Blackfriars-road, that afternoon—I had a check for 197l. 10s., and 18s. or 19s.—I parted with that check to John Jenner, the landlord of the house, and made an arrange
ment for him to meet me at the bank the following morning, to restore it to me—he did not meet me, and I went to his house—I ultimately gave him in charge on the 27th of April—we went before a Magistrate, and I charged him with robbing me of my check—the Magistrate heard my statement, and had Jenner remanded—having left the police-office, I went with the constable to search different houses after the person who had cashed the check—while we were going, I saw the two prisoners, (I had seen Leary at the Yorkshire Stingo the day before, but he was not in the room at the time I gave the check to Jenner)—Leary asked me how I was getting on; I said I hoped to transport the landlord and one or two others, if I could get them—he said, "I suppose you won't care about that, if you could get your money returned"—I said I should not like to let him off so—he said I should not get my money if I went on with it—he said, "I suppose you would rather have your money"—I said, "Yes; I should like to get my money back"—he said, "If you will go down in the country in the morning, you shall have your money returned, every shilling"—in order to get my money, I agreed to go down in the country in the morning, and I said I should detain one of them while the other fetched the money—Leary stopped with me, and Wyatt went and fetched the money—he was away half an hour, or three-quarters of an hour—when he came back he told me he had got a party waiting outside with the money; if I would write him out a receipt for the money, he would go and fetch it—I wrote out a receipt for the full amount of the check, and gave it him—this is the receipt I wrote for 197l. 10s.—he went out and brought me in a bag which contained the money as I thought—I found in it 191l. all in gold—the prisoners told me the sooner I went away the better, and advised me to go as soon as possible for fear I should lose my money again—I wanted to go as soon as I could, to carry my money home—Leary said if I was not in town the next day, Jenner would be liberated, and I did not know any better—I suppose, that was why I was to go in the country, that he might be liberated—I did not make any remark—I went into the country on the following morning—I did not go before the Magistrate—it was in consequence of my receiving this money that I did not go before the Magistrate—on the 1st of May, Wyatt came down to my house at Bawsey; he said he had come down on behalf of Jenner and his wife and family, and I should be doing them a great favour if I did not attend at the Court to go on with the prosecution—he said that Jenner's attorney had told him that if the letter the summons was in, was not rightly directed, I might seal it up and send it back, and they would not know it, and I was not obliged to open it if it were not rightly directed—I said I intended to go on with the prosecution—I intended to come up the following morning, as I had received the summons—I have not
the summons here—I had a constable, and took Wyatt into custody—I came up with him to London on the following morning.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. At that time you had your money? A. I had 191l.—I went before the Magistrate with Jenner; I saw the clerk writing—I cannot tell whether he wrote down what I said—I forget whether what I said was read over to me—I first saw Leary on the 26th of April—Wyatt was not with him then—Leary said nothing to me on the 26th—I saw him alone at various times in the course of the 27th of April—I first saw him with Wyatt on that evening—I met them in the Borough—we went to a public-house, where the money was returned—I did not see Leary after
wards till he was given into custody.

COURT. Q. Were both the prisoners present when that expression was used, "If you go in the country in the morning you shall have every shil
ling?"— A. Yes, both.

MR. PARRY. Q. Were you absent from any examination? A. Yes; on the following day—I live with my father-in-law, a publican, he farms a little land—it was his check—it did not belong to me at all—I am twenty-three years old.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Where was the money returned? A. At a public-house in the Borough—I do not know what house—the money was returned in a bag, which was tied with a string—Wyatt went out to get it, and brought it tied—after I had got the money, he said I had better go away as soon as I could, for fear I should lose it again—I did not see Wyatt again while a I was in town—he came down to my house in the country—he was not in the public-house where I was robbed—I did not see him till I met him at the time he brought back the money—I knew that Jenner's attorney was a person named Roberts—I had seen Roberts attending for Jenner at the Police-court—when Wyatt-came down in the country and mentioned Jenner's attorney, I knew to whom he alluded—Wyatt told me, that Jenner's attorney had told him, that if the letter which contained the summons was not directed right, I need not attend to it, but might re-seal it and send it back.

HENRY BARRY (police-constable M 171.) I took Leary into custody in Martin-street, Union-street, Blackfriars-road, which is where he lives—I told him he was charged with being concerned with Jenner and Wyatt in com
promising a felony—he said he done it to get a few shillings for himself—he did not say with whom he went.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Is Mr. Woodhouse a sergeant of your division? A. Yes—Mr. Cottingham, the Magistrate, directed me to take Leary—I know Mr. Robert's by seeing him attend the Police-court, that is all—I never had any communication with him about this matter—Mr. Cottingham ordered me to get a summons, and write a letter into the country, which I did—that was given out in open Court, Roberts might have heard it—I and Sergeant Woodhouse were at the station when Wyatt was brought there—I did not see Roberts there—I did not see him in company with Wyatt.

MR. PARNELL. Q. When was this given out in Court? A. On the 28th of April—Jenner was before the Magistrate, the prosecutor did not attend, and the Magistrate said, "You had better write a letter, and enclose a sum
mons," which I did.
Mr. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you never been in Mr. Robert's house? A. I never have—I know who you mean, he is a solicitor—I know where he
lives—I never met him at Jenner's—I never was in Jenner's house but once, when I went with Sergeant Woodhouse to search the house.
JOHN WOODHOUSE (police-sergeant M 13.) I produce this receipt.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You know Mr. Roberts, the attorney? A. Yes—I have not seen him to-day—the case was postponed last Sessions, in consequence of Robert's absence—I do not recollect some person who said he came from Roberts, promising that he should be here next Sessions—I heard Roberts called on his subpœna—I think I saw him this day week, at Southwark Police-court—I know him perfectly well by attending the Court—I do not visit him—I was never at his house—I do not think I saw him in company with Wyatt.

MR. BALLANTINE to EDWARD RANSNY. Q. Did Wyatt say, "You need not be afraid of me, I am a hard-working man, the person who got the check cashed is an honest man, and had no idea of defrauding any one by so doing?" A. Yes, that was at the public-house—I did not say that I believed Wyatt was an innocent man, and promise to give him 1l. when he came out of prison—I said I did not know whether he was innocent or not, but he knew where he got the money.

JANE SAUNDERS . My husband is a watch-maker, and lives at No. 1, John-place, Blackfriars-road—I have known Wyatt very well for fourteen or fifteen years—he is a very old acquaintance of my husband's—I saw the check on the Monday night—my husband had it—I knew of his changing it the next morning—I was not present when he received it—I understood from him that he got it from Jenner—about an hour after my husband returned with the money in the morning, I heard there was a charge of stealing the check—I knew my husband had got the money—I went with him to the prosecutor to give the money back—I gave the money to Wyatt, just outside the public-house door—it was in a bag, tied up, just as my husband received it at the Bank—I never went into the public-house.

MR. PARNELL. Q. Where is your husband living? A. At No. 1, John-place—he has been away ever since this matter happened—he went away on the Wednesday following, after the money was given—I do not exactly know where he is now—I do not know what became of the difference of the money—I received the money from my husband, and saw him tie it up myself—I saw the check about eleven o'clock on the Monday night—I did not go with my husband to the Bank—he had to transact some business—it was two dials for his watches—I have them at home now—I saw the money he brought—he never counted it—it was all in gold—I know very little of Leary—I do not think I have spoken to him but once in my life—I never spoke to Jenner before this transaction—my husband has not known him very long—I did not see Jenner about this matter myself—my husband's landlord knows that he brought the check to our house—I saw Mr. Roberts, Mr. Jenner's at
torney—I never spoke to him before the 26th of April—Mr. Jenner brought Mr. Roberts to me in the Old Bailey, last Sessions.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What did they want with you? A. They just wanted to speak to me, to know what Mr. Wyatt was going to do—I told them I did not know anything about it—I was advised not to make any com
munication to Roberts—I think I only spoke to Leary once, that was the night the money was given back—I saw him with Wyatt and the prosecutor then—the only time I spoke to him was while this matter was going on—he has acted throughout to save me and my husband—he is a friend, and an

honest man—my husband has kept out of the way—he has communicated his residence, to come as a witness—I have been married to him fifteen years—he has lived where he does now, for four years, and carried on the same business—he has never been in any trouble or difficulty before—I saw him tie the bag up as he received it from the bankers—in that state I delivered it to Wyatt, at the door—I had not known Jenner—I knew of his calling the same evening that he called.
(Wyatt received a good character.)

LEARY—
GUILTY . Aged 34.

WYATT—
GUILTY. Aged 29. Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—
Confined Three Months.

1531.
SARAH RYAN was indicted
for stealing 1 basket, value 1s.; 1 lock, 3d.; 1 pair of boots, 5s.; 2 handkerchiefs, 1s.; 2 aprons, 1s.; 1 petti
coat, 1s.; 2 pairs of stockings, 8d.; and 5 3/4 d. in copper; the goods and monies of
Honora Collins.

HONORA COLLINS . I am a market-garden woman, and live at Mortlake. On the morning of the 24th of May, I left my boots, my handkerchief, and other things, in the room where I lodged—I had locked them up in a basket—I afterwards met the policeman with the basket and all the things in it—this is it—the things are in it now.

CATHERINE LEE . The prisoner and Collins lodged with me. On this morn
ing the prisoner went out, and I followed her—she had this basket locked up, and her own bundle too—the basket was not broken open.
Prisoner's Defence. I had no work, and I took the basket for a bit of bread; she turned me out, and then she said I was taking away the basket.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

1532.
JOHN JENNER was indicted
for stealing an order for the payment of 197l. 10s.; the property of
Edward Ransby.

EDWARD RANSBY . I reside at Bawsey, in Suffolk. On the 26th of April, I came to town to receive money on my father's account—I received a check for 197l. 10s., payable at Messrs. Prescott's—this is the check—I had about 18s. or 19s. in my pocket besides—I went on that day, about twelve or one o'clock, to the Yorkshire Stingo beer-house in the Blackfriar's-road—I saw the prisoner in front of the bar—he was attending apparently as master—I had a pint of beer—while I was drinking it, a party challenged the prisoner to play at skittles for a sovereign—they went out to play—after they were gone a little while, the prisoner came and invited me to go down in the yard at the back of the house, to see them play—I went and saw them—the land
lord won the game—I heard him ask the man for the sovereign—the man said he had left it with his wife in the bar—after that the prisoner asked me to play a game or two of skittles for a pint of porter—I played a game or two—I lost every game—I then played with another man and lost—Leary (See page 414) was there, but I never saw him play—I played for half-an-hour or three-quarters—before we had finished, several of the men went away—I staid in the skittle-ground—one of them came down and invited me to go up to hear a song—I went up, and after the song, they began to toss for stout and for money—I tossed for stout first, but ultimately for money, with three other men, not the prisoner—when there was a small game I generally won, but when there was a large sum I generally lost—that soon disposed of my 18s. or 19s.—I was then going—the prisoner came in and said, "Do not go, you will win your money back"—I said I had got nothing but a check—he

said if I thought proper to trust it to his care, he had got a friend who would cash it in a few minutes—when I had gone in, the prisoner said to me, "You are a Suffolk man," and he mentioned persons whose names I knew—I cannot recollect whether he said he was from Suffolk—he had not lent me any money before he asked me to trust him with the check—he then lent me half-a-sove
reign to play, while he went to get the check cashed—that was between four and five o'clock—he said he would get it cashed in a few minutes—he was away half an hour, and when he came back I had lost the half-sovereign, and another one likewise—I was half-a-sovereign in debt to the parties I was play
ing with—I asked the prisoner to let me have another half-sovereign—he said, "Yes," and he took out 30s., and put it on the table, and said, "Take that, you will win your money back"—he did not bring change for the check—he said he could not see his friend—he brought the check back—he did not give it to me—I asked him for it back—I asked him if he would take my watch and let me have the check—I had my watch—he was to take that as security for 2l.—he said, "No, I do not like watches"—he said the check was as safe with him as it was with me, and he told me to meet him in the morning at the bankers—I went on playing till I lost 4l. or 5l.—the prisoner still lent the money—as soon as I had lost that, I said I should leave—the prisoner persuaded me to go on further, and ultimately he joined in the game himself, to induce me to play on—I sometimes won a little, and sometimes I lost—I went on till I lost as much as 10l., for which sum I was indebted to the prisoner—I staid at the house till about eight or nine o'clock—I was to meet him next morning at the bankers, at half-past nine o'clock—I was there by a quarter-past nine o'clock—the prisoner did not come—I waited till about ten o'clock—I then went to his house—he was not at home—I sat down in the bar, and the parties who were there, said he was gone to meet me at the bank—I said, "It is no use my going, he will miss me; I will wait"—I waited about three-quarters of an hour—he came home and told me he had lost his cash-box, with my check in it, and 15l. or 20l. of his own money—he did not say anything about the money I owed him—I went to the bankers—I got some of my money back again in the evening of the 27th of April—I had given the prisoner in charge that morning—I got back 191l. from Leary and Wyatt.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you recollect that evening, that you gave the prisoner the check for the purpose of being changed? A. Yes, that was the object for which I gave it him—he did not tell me when he came back, that he had been to the bank, and was too late—I parted with the check for the purpose of getting it changed into money—I should say I was sober throughout—I am a Suffolk man—I have been in London a few times—I have not been in the habit of going to public-houses—I never played at skittles, or tossed up before in my life—on the following morning, when the prisoner told me he had been robbed of his cash-box, with my check and money of his own, he wanted to go to the Police-station to give information—I did not ask him, before he said anything to me, if he could get the check changed—I only said I had one—I should have left the house—he put that forward that he would get it changed for me—I am not positive whether he produced the check when he returned—this is the watch which I wanted to deposit—it is silver—I went on to borrow a sum of 10l. in the whole—I afterwards borrowed 10s., and left the house.

BERNARD BARTON . I am a clerk at Messrs. Prescott's bank. On the 26th of April, about one minute past five o'clock, the prisoner came into the office, brought this check, and wanted it cashed—he was very anxious to get it

changed—I thought he was a countryman, and I was very anxious to do it for him, but we had all closed our books—I did not do it—he said he would give a sovereign for it—I did not understand that he did that for a bribe, but from his anxiety to get it done—the check was presented again the next morning by another person, as soon as the doors were open—gold was given for it.

JOHN WOODHOUSE (police-constable M 13) On the morning of the 27th of April the prisoner came to the station, he said, "This morning, while I was out a few minutes, my cash-box was stolen from my bar-parlour, containing a check belonging to this gentleman, and three 5l. notes of my own property."
NOT GUILTY .

1533.
MARY ANN MARSHALL was indicted
for stealing 1lb. 20s. weight of bacon, value 1s., the goods of
William Musselwhite; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY SHIELDS . I am servant to William Musselwhite, a cheesemonger, in Lower-marsh, Lambeth—at eleven o'clock in the morning of the 3rd of June I saw the prisoner take a piece of bacon, and put it under her arm—she in
quired the price of several other pieces—I told her the price, and she put them down again—she still held this piece under her arm—she walked away—I stopped her, and told her I wanted the piece of bacon under her arm—she took it form under her arm, and said she was only having a lark, she was only playing—it was my master's bacon.

Prisoner's Defence. I thought I would have half a pound of it; I asked the price of another piece; that was 10d., this was only 9d.; he asked which I wanted; I said I wanted the best piece; the wind blew my shawl over it, and he said "I will give you in charge, I think you want to steal it;" I have four orphans; I have been in a bad state of health for ten year; I made away with the last thing I had in the world.

WILLIAM POCOCK (police-sergeant F 14) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at this Court, by the name of Mary Ann Ryan—(read—Convicted 2nd Feb., 1846. confined one year)—the prisoner is the person—she had convicted before that.

GUILTY . Aged 46.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1534.
MARY TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing 3 pewter pots, value 5s. 6d., the property of
Daniel William Saunders.

THOMAS HIGHLAND . I am in the service of Daniel William Saunders, a publican, at Rotherhithe—on the 31st of May, at half-past eleven o'clock I re
ceived information—I went out and saw the prisoner—I asked her if she would allow me to look under her shawl—she did, and I found one quart pot—I was taking her back, and going along she dropped two other pots—they were all my masters—she had no business with either of them.
TIMOTHY LEARY . I was standing outside the window—I saw the prisoner sitting on the seat—I saw her take one pot and put it under her shawl—I told the potman of it.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 31st of May I went to Deptford to purchase some articles—I met some friends who had come from Woolwich—we had some ale, and as I had nothing to eat since the morning, the ale made me unable to see—I did not know what I was doing—my friend before starting from me would make me have a drop of rum—they then went home—I had a small basket with some eatables in it—it had no handles, so I carried it in my apron—I fell asleep—I was not sober—I still kept my apron up—I got up and took

a pot which was on the table and was going to the ditch to fetch some water—when I got half way, the potboy came and took the pot out of my hand—he asked what I had got in my apron—I showed my basket—he said, "No, you have got a pot"—he took me back, and after I had passed some persons who were drinking, I saw a man throw a pot off the table, and he said to the boy "There is another for you"—he went and took it—I told him he ought to be ashamed to do it—he said I should pay for all—I cannot account for the post being in my apron, except some boys put it in.

GUILTY . Aged 57.—
Confined Two Months.

1535.
GEORGE STEVENS was indicted
for stealing 5 oz. weight of plated copper, value 4d.; 2 carriage-lamps, 15s.; 6 lamp-irons, 4s. 6d.; 36lbs. weight of solder, 1l. 17s.; 17 lbs. weight of copper, 2l. 8 lbs. weight of brass, 8s.; 15 lamp-glasses, 9s.; 12 lamp-bands, 9s.; 8 lamp-heads, 12s.; 20 lamp-chimneys, 4s.; 46 lamp-backs, 8s.; 31 lamp-rings, 10s.; 12 lamp-boxes, 6s.; 1 lb. weight of iron wire, 3d.; and 4 bolts, 1s.; the property of
Richard Brown, his master; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 64.—
Confined One Year.

1536.
HUGH SUMMERS was indicted
for stealing 7 watches, value 10l.; the property of
Robert Short, in his dwelling-house; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which h pleaded

GUILTY .* Aged 13.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1537.
JAMES ATKINS was indicted
for stealing 1 cart, value 6l.; the property of
Charles Norville.

FRANCES NORVILLE . I am the wife of Charles Norville—we live at Brixton—I know the prisoner—in May I had a cart for sale—I put it in front of the house—the prisoner pressed me to send it to an auction-room, and said he would take it—I said I would speak to my husband about it—I got his leave, and sent my son up with it—it remained unsold till last Feb., and then the prisoner went to Mr. Lloyd and gave him instructions for it to be sold—I went to Mr. Lloyd, and he had sold the cart by private contract—I have had no money for it—I did not authorize any one to sell it.
CHARLES NORVILLE . I am the husband of Frances Norville—I did not authorize the prisoner to sell the cart—I have not received any money for it.

WILLIAM HENRY LLOYD . I am an auctioneer—the cart was brought to me by the prisoner and a lad—it was deposited with me to be sold at my auction, which was every Thursday—it was not to go under 4l.—the pri
soner said he had been doing business for the party whose cart it was, and he should not like it to go under 4l.—I sold it and gave the money to the prisoner.
Prisoner. I received the cart on the 19th of May—Mr. Norville's bill amounted to 6l. 15s. 6d., and now his bill amounts to 20l. 14s. 6d.

CHARLES NORVILE
re-examined. I do not owe him a farthing—I did not authorize him to sell the cart.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not put the horse in the cart? A. No—I did not know you were going to take it—I thought my son would take it—I never saw you till the following day, when you told me you had been to Mr. Lloyd's—I
did not employ you in Aug., 1845, to get up a fair—I might have been in the field when the attorney and some persons came to take possession.
COURT. Q. But did you employ the prisoner? A. No.
Prisoner. I received 4l. 7s. out of 20l. odd. Witness. I do not owe him a penny.

GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Confined Nine Months.

1538.
JAMES HURLEY was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 1l., the goods of
Walter Crutchley; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS PARNELL . I live with Mr. Walter Crutchley, a tailor, in High-street, in the Borough. On the 24th of May I received information about a fishing-coat—a woman came in with the ticket which had the price of the coat on it—we then missed the coat from the block.

MARY HOOPER . I am the wife of George Hooper—we live in Falcon-court, in the Borough. On the 24th of May I was standing at the top of the court, and saw the prisoner—he turned the corner very quickly—he had a coat hanging over him arm—I could not tell what it was till he got by me, and then he took the ticket off the coat and threw it away—I took it up, and charged him with stealing it—he ran away—I took the ticket to the prose
cutor's, and they missed the coat off the block, which was inside the door.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see me take the coat? A. No, I had a suspicion, because you took the ticket off and threw it away—I saw your face—you were closer to me than you are now—you went round to the right—I had seen you so often, that I could not be mistaken in you—I can swear you are the person—you had the coat on your left arm.

HENRIETTA MASTERS . I live in Falcon-court. On the 24th of May I saw the prisoner in the prosecutors' shop—he afterwards passed me with a coat on his arm—I saw him take the ticket off it and throw it down—Mr. Hooper took it up—I am certain the prisoner is the man.

THOMAS HAY (police-sergeant M 9.) On the 1st of June, after a long run and a severe struggle, I took the prisoner, and took him to the station—he ran off immediately he saw me looking at him—he was identified by one of the witnesses as the man—I have the ticket which I got at Mr. Crutchley's shop.

MARY HOOPER
re-examined. This is the ticket I picked up.

THOMAS PARNELL
re-examined. The coat that is missed had this ticket on it, and it was the property of Mr. Walter Crutchley.

Prisoner's Defence. Does it stand to reason, that a person walking the street with a coat, could be known by a stranger? I should have had wit
nesses to prove I was at Stepney fair.
GEORGE WILD (police-constable M 94) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 21st of Sept., 1846, and confined six months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Year.

1539.
ELLEN TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing 1 penny, the money of
Charles Sutton, her master.

CHARLES SUTTON . I keep the Union Arms, Union-row, Clapham—the prisoner was in my service—I put some marked money on the top of my till—the prisoner cleaned the bar, and I found a marked penny in her drawer up stairs, that was lost last Monday morning—I missed that penny immedi
ately.

Prisoner. A gentleman came, had a steak, and gave me that penny for cooking it; you said you could not swear to it. Witness. This the penny—I know it by some shot-marks on it, and it is bent—I had it from Thurs
day till Monday—I had not an opportunity of marking it before—I heard the money jink on Thursday, which excited my suspicion—she lent my man 10s. on Saturday—5s. of it was in halfpence, which she had no honest means of getting.

JAMES LONG (police-constable V 316) I searched the prisoner's box, and found this penny—I found one shilling and three halfpence in coppers in the soil of privy—three of the pieces are claimed by the prosecutor as marked—one is an Irish halfpenny, another has eleven dots on it.

CHARLES SUTTON
re-examined. I picked them out as being very curiously marked—this occurred early in the morning, before I had done any business—I came down in the morning, and put these into the till—the prisoner went into the bar—I walked to the door—I then came in and missed them—no one had been in the place but her and me.

Prisoner. There was a sovereign I found in your bed, a half-crown I found on the staircase, and a fourpenny-piece; I gave it all to you. Witness. Yes, that is true, that might have been in the way of business—I had no suspicion of her till this.

Prisoner's Defence. I never touched his money; what money I have got I worked hard for; have been with him seven months, and never wronged him of a farthing in my life; I had 11l. a year; all his books are in the drawer in which that penny was found; all my things and his are mixed together.
NOT GUILTY .

1540.
ELLEN TAYLOR was again indicted
for stealing 2 pence and 1 halfpenny, the monies of
Charles Sutton, her master.

CHARLES SUTTON . I did not examine the contents of the till so as to know what they were—I have not been so particular as I ought to have been—we have generally placed the female servant as a confidential person there—on my charging the prisoner, she went into the yard, and we found in the privy 1s. 1 1/2 d.—on this penny piece is T. P., on this other, eleven dots, and the other has a mark—the penny-piece I missed on Monday, morning, I put in with the others—there is only myself and my brother living there—he is ill in bed, he cannot identify this coin.
NOT GUILTY .

1541.
ROBERT HAINES,
DANIEL CONLEY , and
JAMES COCK
LING were indicted for
stealing 800 lbs. weight of iron, value 3l., the goods of the
Southwark and Vauxhall Water Company; and that Haines had been before convicted of felony.

ALEXANDER CHISHOLM . I am foreman to Mr. Eyer, contractor to the South-wark and Valuxhall Water Company—I was before the Magistrate when some iron water-pipe was produced—it was the property of the Southwark and Vauxhall Water Company—I had taken them up in the Camberwell New-road to lay down larger ones—they were taken up on the Thursday, and I saw them on Saturday, at the merchant's where they had been sold—I know the prisoner Haines, he was labourer to Mr. Hayward—I have seen him about the Company's works.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Haines applied to you for work after he had been discharged by his employer? A. Yes, I intended to make

inquiries about him—these pipes were lying in the road—I know them by the size, having pipes on the spot, and this pipe being gone form the Cam
berwell New-road.

THOMAS GORE . I am a labourer in the service of the contractor for the Southwark and Vauxball Water Company. On Saturday afternoon, the 15th of May, between three and four o'clock, I saw a van coming along Bowyer-lane with a nine inch branch and a five inch outlet, iron water pipes, in it—I told the driver there was not room to go by—I was shooting a load of rub
bish—I saw the van coming, and took my horse's head, and I noticed these pipes in the van—Haines was sitting behind the van—as soon as he saw me he put his hand before his eyes—I had known him by our working at the same farm—there were four persons in the van—I did not take notice of the others—the van was coming form Camberwell New-road—I knew there had been a quantity of water pipes lying in that road—I did not go to where that pipe had been—I gave information to Dooley—the pipes I saw in the van were of the same description as those I saw lying in the Camberwell New-road—I am pretty well sure Cockling was the man driving the van.

Cross-examined. Q. How many person were there in the van? A. Four—I am certain there were four—I did not speak to either of them—it never struck me to do so till the van went by so quick—I was not exactly acquainted with Haines, only by working with him—I did not know either of the others—I have had no quarrel with Haines—he has worked in the same employ as I have—I have put down the pipe, and he has paved the boxes afterwards—he is paviour—that is three of four months ago I suppose—he was getting his living by hard work at the time I knew him—I do not know how it was I did not speak to him on this occasion—I did not notice him till the van had gone by—there were four in the van, and Haines was in the hind part.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Are there any one of the others that you know to be there beside Haines? A. I am pretty sure Cockling was there, but I am not right down sure—the way the van was going, would have led to Bankside.

JOSEPH DONOVAN . I am in the employ of Mr. Plimbey, of Bankside. On that Saturday afternoon a van came, and brought a quantity of iron pipe—Mr. Chisholm came three or four hours afterwards, and claimed some of the pipe that was brought in that van—Haines brought the pipe—he gave me the name of Smith—I bought it of him at 3s. a cwt.—I did not see any of the other prisoners there—he came to me by himself—he and one of our labour
ers got the iron out of the van—Haines stated it was his own iron—I know a great many persons who come, but Haines was quite a stranger.

ROBERT BRANFORD (police-sergeant M 12) I took Haines on Saturday night, the 15th of May—I told him it was for stealing a quantity of iron from the Camberwell New-road—he said he was in the van that day, but he had nothing to do with the iron—I took Cockling on the 17th of May—he said he had been employed by two men to carry some iron from the Camber
well New-road to Mr. Plimbey's.

Cockling's Defence. On that Saturday morning, at half-past seven o'clock, I went to a house in Russell-street, Bermondsey, and moved some goods to Bankside; when I had half unloaded, a man came and said, was I engaged? I said, there was my master; he said he wanted some iron moved form Cam
berwell New-road, and some men would meet me in Union-street; I went; two men jumped up, and took me to Camberwell New-road, they said that was the iron; I was employed to carry it; my master authorized me to carry it.

FRANCIS JENNERY . I am a carman, and live at No. 55, Bermondsey-street—Cockling drove my van for about four months, during my illness—on that morning I was unloading a load of goods at Bankside, and I was en
gaged by an unknown man to fetch some iron from Camberwell—he said the carman was to meet him against St. George's church, to fetch some iron from Camberwell, to bring it to Plimbey's—he did not agree about any price—I left that to the man after he dad done the work—I sent Cockling—he came back about four o'clock in the afternoon, and gave me 6s.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Where were you unloading the goods? A. The load came from Russell-street to Bankside—it was ordered at half-past six o'clock—they were unloading about half-past nine in the morning—I do not know what morning it was—I did not put it down—it was on a Saturday—a person came up almost against Mr. Plimbey's—he hardly spoke two words to me—I do not know the name of the person from whom I took the goods—it was from a private house—the ladies had gone into the country for their health—they were not unloaded at any house or wharf, but on the shore at Bankside—I do not know whose house they were fetched from in Russell-street—my carman went—I was ill in bed at the time—I am ill now, I am not fit to be here—I got up about eight o'clock—I had my breakfast, and walked to Bankside—I went by myself—they were then unloading these goods—my carman's name is Cockling down here—I do not know whether his name is Conley—I only know him by driving for me—I only know his name is "Cockling" down on the subpœna—I cannot swear whether Haines is the man who came up while we were unloading—I cannot swear to any man—I went up to the Magistrate, but I was too late—I knew my man was an innocent man—I was too ill to go before the Magistrate again—I have been ill these ten months—I never saw the man before or since who came to my carman—I did not notice whether he was tall or short, nor how he was dressed—I did not inquire where he lived, or what he was about—I have no impression whether he might be a gentleman or a common working man—I had but two words with him, and did not notice him—I had no character with Cockling—he behaved very well to me.

JAMES JENNINGS . I am a master mariner—I was in the police—I produce a certificate of Haines's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 23rd of Oct., 1837, and confined six months)—he is the person.

HAINES—
GUILTY .

CONLEY and COCKLING—
NOT GUILTY .

1542.
ROBERT HAINES was again indicted
for stealing 1,100lbs. weight of iron, value 6l.; the goods of
Joseph Threlfall Carter.

JOSEPH DONOVAN . I am employed by Mr. Plimbey, of Bankside. On the 15th of May the prisoner brought some iron to our place—a part of it was afterwards seen by Mr. Carter, and Mr. Sutton, the policeman, took pos
session of it—there was 19cwt. of iron in the van—I paid 2l. 17s. for the whole of it.
ROBERT BRANFORD (police-sergeant M 12.) I took possession of the iron—a part of it was seen by Mr. Carter on Monday, the 17th—he claims a quantity of it—it Mr. Sutton saw it.
GRORGE SUTTON . I have seen a quantity of this pipe in the possession of the policeman—it is the property of Mr. Joseph Threlfall Carter, my master—it

was got from the Well-house, at Sydenham, on Saturday, the 15th of May, by the persons in the van—I saw four men in the van—they came to me as I was at work there between twelve and one o'clock, and said, "We have come for this piping"—I thought my employer had sent them, and let them take it—Conley was one of the men who came—I cannot speak to the others.

THOMAS GORE . I saw the van coming from Camberwell New-road to Bowyer-lane—that would be the way to come from Sydenham—I am quite sure Haines is one who was in the van—I saw a considerable quantity of iron in the van—I did not take particular notice what iron it was—there was a quantity of water-pipe in it.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you not swear before the Magistrate that you were quite certain Haines and Cockling were two of the men in the cart? A. No—this is my mark to this deposition—(the deposition being read, stated, "I saw the two prisoners. Haines and Cockling, in the van—Cockling was driving—Haines was in the van—Haines knew me—he put up his arm to prevent my seeing him—I am quite certain Haines and Cockling were the two men.")—I said there were four men—Haines was one—I am pretty well, sure Cockling was the man who was driving—I saw the van about four o'clock.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You gave information of this? A. Yes, to Dooley, whom I was driving rubbish for.
ALEXANDER CHISHOLM . I received information of this from Mr. Plowman.
Cross-examined. Q. Who is Mr. Plowman? A. He is foreman to Mr. Hayward—he told me of this, and that some of our men had been pursuing the thieves.
JOSEPH THRELFALL CARTER . This pipe is mine—I gave no authority to any person to have it removed.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the value of it? A. 7l. or 8l.—there are several lengths of pipe of a very remarkable sort—I suppose hardly any of such a sort in the trade—if a person gave 2l. 17s. for all mine, and 8cwt. in addition, it is not anything like the value of the pipe—old iron sells very low.

JOSEPH DONOVAN
re-examined. Q. How was this iron when it was brought to you? A. All broken up, of no use but for melting again—I should not have bought it for old iron if it had not been broken.
Cross-examined. Q. What time did it get to your place? A. As near as I can recollect, about five o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.

1543.
WILLIAM GEORGE LIPSCOMB was indicted
for embezzle
ment.

JOHN PEEL . I live in the New-cut, Lambeth, and am a printer. The prisoner was in my service as lately as the 20th of April—a person named Snelling was indebted to me for some work done—it was the prisoner's duty to receive money on my account—the course of business was for the money to be entered in the cash-book by the person who received it, the day of the month, and what sort of money was received, and to put the money through a crevice into the desk—I asked the prisoner if Mr. Smith had paid him 9s.—he said I should find it in the book—I have examined the book, and I do not find it entered—the prisoner has not accounted to me for a sum paid by Mr. Snelling.

Prisoner. The money has been paid to me, and not entered in the cash-book; he asked me if I had received Mr. Smith's; I told him I had; I received the three sums, the 9s. 6d., 9s., and 1l. 2s. 6d., but unfortunately did not enter them in the cash-book.

JOHN PEEL
re-examined. Q. How many day's delay was there in the entry in the cash-book? A. I had not questioned him about Mr. Snelling's money—I only asked him about Mr. Smith's—I discharged him for intoxication—I wondered how he got the money.

RICHARD SNELLING , Jun. I am clerk to Messrs. Shield and Co. I knew the prisoner in the prosecutor's service—on the 3rd of April he brought this bill of 1l. 2s. 6d.—I paid him, and he receipted the bill.

CHARLES SMITH . I knew the prisoner as servant to the prosecutor—he brought me a bill of 9s. on the 15th of April—he told me Mr. Peel was very poorly—I told him to receipt the bill—I gave him the money.
NATHANIEL FREDERICK OKEY . I keep the Hero of Waterloo, in Waterloo-road. The prisoner produced this bill for 9s. 6d. to me on the 19th of April—I paid him the amount—he receipted the bill.
HENRY CHAMPION (police-constable F 107.) I apprehended the prisoner.

JOHN PEEL
re-examined. Q. Did the prisoner ever either of these bills in the cash-book? A. He did not—he he did not communicate to me of his own accord that he had received them—he did not admit that he had re
ceived any of them, and omitted to enter it—I spoke to him about Mr. Smith's—he said he had entered that—the others I have found out since—he made no communication to me about them—I discharged him about the 20th of April—he did not leave my place till the 24th.

Prisoner. It might have passed my memory; I have been in the habit of receiving money, and always entered it in the cash-book: I have omitted to enter this, but if I had been disposed to have made off with money, I might have made off with more than this; I had a great deal of money; I have delivered this money faithfully up to Mr. Peel. Witness. His duty was to put in into the desk, not to give it to me, but put it down in the book—I compared the money with the book day by day—I did not find there was too much—it always tallied with the book—two or three persons take money—they have order to put down what money they receive, and the description of it—I found no such sums as these in the desk—I found no paper that dis
closed he had received this money, not any money unaccounted for—I am able to swear that the 1l. 2s. 6d. was not paid to me in the shop.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1544.
MARGARET FLANAGAN was indicted for
stealing 1 shawl, value 30s., the goods of
Ahijah Henry Stephens, her master; and
JOHAN
NAH FLANAGAN
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

SUSANNAH STEPHENS . I am the wife of Ahijah Henry Stephens—we live in Surrey-place—Margaret Flanagan was in my service for about five months—I had a character with her. On the 31st of May I went to my drawer for a gown-piece, and missed it—I asked her about it—she denied knowing any
thing about it—I had her taken into custody, and on the 1sy of June I missed a shawl—her mother, Johannah Flanagan, gave up the duplicate, and the shawl was found at Mr. Russell's, the pawnbrokers—Johannah Flanagan did not come to tomy house—she had noopportunity of taking the shawl—I went to Mr. Russell's, Which is about five minutes' walk from my house; and while I was there, I saw Johannah Flanagan pass—the officer ran and stopped

her—I heard her say that she had told her daughter to take the things from me, and if the officer went home with her she would give up the duplicate of the black satin shawl—she told me that she wanted money, and that she told her daughter to take something from me to get the money.

JAMES COLDMAN (police-constable M 159.) I received charge of Margaret Flanagan on the 31st of May, at her master's; and I saw Johannah Flanagan near Mr. Russell's shop—I got from her a duplicate of a shawl—she said that Margaret Flanagan had told her her mistress would be in want of the green shawl which was then in pawn; and she told her to get something else to get it out—Margaret Flanagan said that her mother told her to bring things home, and she had taken this shawl home, and her mother had pawned it—this is the shawl—the duplicate was given up to the pawnbroker on account of his giving up the shawl, which the Magistrate ordered me to keep.
MRS. STEPHENS re-examined. This is my shawl.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

MARGARET FLANAGAN—
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined One Month.

JOHANNAH FLANAGAN—
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined One Year.

p.hi: The prisoner were recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutrix.

div1.p:
1545.
JOHN AMBROSE was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
John Squire, a peace officer, and
rescuing from his custody one
John Witty, charged with felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1546.
JAMES LOFTUS BROCK was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Ann Brock, and cutting and wounding her on the left arm, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

ANN BROCK . I am the prisoner's wife—he is a lieutenant in the army on half-pay—we were married in 1820, and have three children—he is addicted to drink, and when under the influence of drink he is generally very violent—he has told me that he was not right in his head at times, and to be cautious what I said to him when he was under the influence of drink—he said he did not know what would be the end of it, as he knew his head was bad—we live at No. 105, East-street—on the 3rd of June he came home about half-past ten in the morning—he had been out all night, I think—he was very much agitated indeed—he had been drinking—he went into Mr. Crossland, the landlord's place—I could not hear what was said, but I could hear the tone of his voice—I do not know that he spoke to me—he kept talking to himself for two or three hours—I went down to the yard—he followed me round the yard—I went round because I was afraid he was going to strike me—he had not said anything to make me think so, but I saw he was in a violent passion—he did not say what he was in a passion about—he went up stairs, I remained down till nearly twelve o'clock—he re
mained quite still, and then I went up stairs—when I got up he came behind me with a knife—I did not see it, but I felt him stab me in my arm—he made no observation at the time, that I heard—I ran out of the room, went down stairs, and got away—I did not hear him speak—my recollection is not more faint now than it was before the Magistrate—he said nothing after he stabbed me—there was nothing said in the house at the time about my life—I do not know what was said out of the house, for the prisoner and the policeman walked on together—my son was in the room, and struck the prisoner's arm—I cannot say in what position the prisoner's hand was then,

as he was behind me—he stabbed me on the outside of my arm, at the back—he said nothing about the children that morning, that I heard—he has wounds in his head, which appear to give greater effect to drink—I am certain he is not right in his head at times—the knife went in at one side of my arm and came out at the other—I hope you will show him as much mercy as possible, I freely forgive him.

JAMES LENIGAR BROCK . I am a son of the prisoner and prosecutrix, and live in the house—the prisoner was out all the Wednesday—he came home about ten o'clock next morning, and went out again almost immediately—I did not see him follow my mother at that time, he went down stairs after her about half an hour after that—he came back in the first instance, and spoke to me—my mother returned up stairs shortly before twelve o'clock—she came into the room, my father went behind her, and stabbed her with a knife in the arm—he had been quiet for a short time previous to that—the knife had been lying open on the table—this produced is it—he usually carried it with him—there was a table in the room, my mother went behind it, and he followed her, and struck at her a back-handed blow with the knife in his right hand—I cannot say what part he aimed at, it took effect on the left arm—I rushed forward and struck his arm as he was in the act of striking—I cannot be certain whether that diverted the blow from the direction it would otherwise have taken—I believe it is the opinion of the surgeon that the blow was struck very closely indeed to the heart—he struck from behind—I do not think he introduced his arm so as to strike before her—he made no observation at the time, but followed her down stairs after he had stabbed her—he then said he wished it had gone to her heart—about half an hour previous to the transaction, he said the flesh was drunk, but the spirit was not—my mother had not been in the room above a minute, when he followed her be
hind the table—he had been apparently quiet perhaps about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour before she came up—I had heard him use expressions of resentment on other occasions—he has said that when he was in that state of mind he could not be accountable for the consequences, and he could not tell what the consequences would be.

Prisoner. Q. How old are you? A. Twenty-one last November—I have never been from under your roof—I never knew a person to knock at your door and accuse you of acting rascally or dishonestly to us, or of cloth
ing us otherwise than at your own expense—you have nothing except your half-pay.

FREDERICK BROCK . I am a son of the prisoner and prosecutrix—I saw my father when he first came in—he came up stairs—he had no knife then, it was in his pocket, I suppose—about half an hour after he came in, he took it out of his pocket, and ran down stairs after my mother, and ran her up again—the knife was open—when he came up again he shut the knife, and put it into his pocket—my mother remained down stairs till about a quarter to twelve o'clock, she then came into the room again, and went round the table—he fol
lowed her round, went behind her, and stabbed her—when he was in the act, my brother struck his arm to ward off the blow—it was a back-handed blow—it pointed towards the fleshy part of her arm—he appeared to be striking to
wards the left breast, before my brother struck his arm and diverted the blow—at the station he said he wished he had finished her—he was at the station about half-past one—he had been home more than two hours—he had carried the knife in his pocket for two years.
Prisoner. Q. Was I at the station at time I made the observation you allude to? A. Yes; you had made it before—my brother James was with

me at the station—I was seventeen last Aug—I have never been from under your roof—I never knew a person know at your door, and accuse you of being rascally in your conduct, or clothing and feeding us otherwise than at your own expense—you have nothing except your half-pay.

JURY. Q. On what terms did they generally live; did they quarrel? A. His temper has always been very violent, especially when he has had drink—he was affectionate sometimes—my mother never did anything to aggravate him.

JURY to JAMES LENIGAR BROCK. On what terms did your father and mother live? A. He was tolerably quiet when he was sober, but when he was drunk he was violent—he was in the habit of getting too much to drink, I should say, about once a fortnight—when he was not in liquor his conduct to my mother was tolerably quiet and kind—I consider his head is affected—he never drinks spirits, only beer and ale.

Prisoner. Q. Have I ever shown any partiality to one in preference to an
other of you? A. No.

JAMES COKER (police-constable L 88.) I was called in about half-past eleven o'clock, and found the prosecutrix's left arm bleeding—the prisoner said he wished it had gone to her heart—he was very much affected at the time—it was not altogether with drink, I believe he was excited—he had the ap
pearance of having been drinking a little, but not to take much effect upon him—I did know him before—on the way to the station he said he should not mind being hung for her—he appeared angry.
Prisoner. Q. Where was I when I said I wished it had gone to her heart? A. In the station, and in going there as well.

EDWARD CROSSLAND . I am a carpenter, and live at No. 105, East-street, Lambeth; I am the son of the landlord. The prisoner, his wife, and three sons lodged with my father—I heard Mr. Brock call out, "Murder!" and they all ran down stairs—when Mr. Brock came down stairs I noticed her arm bleeding—I turned up her sleeve, and found she was stabbed in the arm—when the prisoner came in in the morning I was in the front parlour—when he is sober we are very good friends—he is quiet when sober—I cannot say that, when he is intoxicated; he is violent—I do not live up stairs with them—he has used threats to his wife—the night before this took place he made use of the ex
pression he would throttle his wife—I cannot say whether he was intoxicated then—I was in bed at the time.
Prisoner. Q. Did you ever hear anybody accuse me of acting rascally or dishonestly, or of clothing my children otherwise than at my own expense? A. No.
JURY. Q. Did he state any cause why he should throttle his wife? A. They had been having words—he made no accusation against her.

MICHAEL LAWRENCE MASON . I live at No. 5, High-street, Newington. On the 3rd of June the constable brought Mr. Brock to my surgery about noon—I examined her left arm—there was a triangular wound through the muscles at the back part of the bone—it appeared to have been done by an instrument thrust through—there was one wound above, and one underneath the arm—the cut was continued downwards towards the elbow, almost forming a flap—if it had been continued a little longer the flesh would have been quiet disengaged from below—it did not appear to be made with the same blow, at the same time—there was a stab, and then an extension of the cut, as of a second action of the hand—it might have been done in drawing the knife out, because above the length was two inches, and below, where the knife had passed through, an inch and a quarter—the blow was behind the done—it passed through the muscles—it

went down to the bone—it was through the thickness of the arm—upwards of an inch and a half of the knife went in—the knife produced probably would cause the wound—it is beveled on both sides, which formed the triangle—it was not of a dangerous character—if it had passed in front of the bone it might have been so.
Q. How near the position of the heart was the wound? A. It was in a true line between the fourth and eighth rib.

Prisoner. Q. Could not the appearance that you speak of be produced by a person striking my arm after the wound was inflicted? A. It might, or the extension might be produced by drawing the knife out.

COURT. Q. Supposing the knife to be in the wound, a blow under or above would lengthen it? A. Yes—it might be attributable to that cause, or to the mode of drawing out the knife—I think the arm must have been close to the breast when the side was struck, and that the prisoner stood somewhat backwards—I think it was a back-handed stroke.
Prisoner. Q. Your opinion is that I must have been in front? A. No.

COURT. Q. A person near the arm, but behind, could have made that stab? A. Certainly; but the arm is capable of being moved in so many positions that it is impossible to say where the blow was aimed—I question whether the prisoner is of sound mind.

Prisoner's Defence. I have heard the evidence, but that is all I know of the transaction; I know no more about it than as a dream; my temper is bad at times; my mind has been repeatedly irritated; my wife knows my temper to be hasty; how could a poor lieutenant on half-pay bring up a family if he spent his money in drunkenness? I commit my soul to my God, and my person to my fellow-creatures; this will be depriving me of my half-pay.

COURT to MRS. BROCK. Q. Has the prisoner ever shown any extrav
gance of mind, or want of balance of mind? A. Repeatedly—he has laid on the bed like a man raving mad, beating the cloths, and tearing himself when intoxicated—when he has been sober he has got up at one or two o'clock in the morning and smoked his pipe at the window, and said, "Oh dear me!"—he has been wounded in the head—he has got a sear—I never applied to any medical man to induce him to put him under any partial restraint—I always considered that if he lived many years he would go out of his mind, raving mad—as he got old he got worse—more than twenty years ago he leaped through a window, glass, frame and all—a person had locked him in—he was then sober—the other day he told me it was a wonder he did not go through the wall instead of the door; and in many other things he has spoken very inconsistently—he reads a good deal, and instructs his children, but he scarcely ever has patience to hear them—he would work himself up in such a way that he could scarcely do it—sometimes he would be in doors a month or six weeks together, and then these fits come on, and he would go out at one or two o'clock in the night.

JURY. Q. Did he complain of his head? A. Yes—if he goes to stoop he puts his hand to his head and says, "Oh my head!"—he would not stoop to do anything—that is when he has been drinking—it has always been my impression that he would go out of his mind—he was very quiet some-times; you would not know a person was in the house, and sometimes his tongue would begin and go on till two or three o'clock in the night, without knowing what he was talking about—he has been to the station-house re
peatedly and given information against two policemen—a man who heard his conversation at the window called him a crack-brained fool for the way he was going on, knowing he was not right—it was at certain times, about the new and full moon, that he was worse.

hi.rs: NOT GUILTY, being Insane.

div1.p:
1547.
MARY ANN SMITH was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 guard-chain, 4l.; 1 braquest-chain, 1l. 10s.; and 1 sixpence; the property of
John William, from his person.

(the prosecutor stated his real name to be Douglas, that he had only assumed the name of Williams in this transaction for the purpose of conceal
ment, and had never gone by that name before.)
NOT GUILTY .

1548.
WILLIAM GRIFFIN was indicted
for stealing 6 half-crowns, 3 shillings, and 4 pence, the monies of
Samuel Lindsey, his master.

SAMUEL LINDSEY . I am a grocer, and live in New-cut, Lambeth. The prisoner was seven months in my service, and came as a single man, but he is married—he lived in the house till within about six weeks or two months—I frequently missed articles from the stock, and watched a female who came on Saturday the 15th of May, she came to the shop when we were very busy—she did not ask for anything, but tendered him half-a-sovereign—he gave her 18s. 4d. out of it—I stopped him, and asked him if he knew her—he said, certainly not, that he never saw her before in his life—she said not ask for anything—he gave her 3s. 6d. worth of goods, and gave her 18s. 4d. out of a half-sovereign—I charged him with robbing me—the women said in his presence that it was a sovereign she gave him—she bolted off, and never came back—I went to the prisoner's lodging and asked for him—they said he was not within—I asked for Mr. Griffin, they said she was within, and to my surprise I found a wife and three children—I had previously seen two or three sove
reigns and two half-sovereigns in the till, and the half-sovereign he put in would make three half-sovereigns—I stood by him, and am certain he took half-a-sovereign from her—I found half-a-sovereign more in the till than there was a minute before—the women left her basket behind her—she went away to fetch a witness to prove she had a sovereign—I found from four to six pounds of sugar at the prisoner's lodging—I cannot swear to it—having received half-a-sovereign, the prisoner pretended to give change for a sovereign—he gave more than the change.

cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. He lived with you four months? A. Yes, from the 20th of Sept.—he lived in the house with me most of the time—he had left off sleeping there—he left my service once, came again in a fortnight or three week, and wished to come back—I took him in, and then he proposed to live out of the house—if I had known he was married I would not have taken him—I cannot recollect whether there were two or three sovereigns in the till, but there were three half-sovereigns—I had looked just before the transaction, and know there were no more sovereigns, and I looked at it afterwards—there was probably 5l. worth of silver there—it was a little after eleven o'clock at night—I had four persons serving in the shop—there is more than one till—the shopmen would put gold into the till, and take it out if they wanted change—after the woman found that I detected it she said she had given him a sovereign—we had seen her very often at the place—the prisoner was at the bottom of the counter—she came right through the shop down to him—I went and stood next to him—I cannot say now whether I told him to attend to the customer—when we are busy he serves—I sometimes do call him—there were ten or twelve customer in the shop at the time—I stood close to him—what he received from her he dropped into the till—our rule is to put gold on the counter, and take the change out, but he opened the till, and dropped in what he took before he took out the change—I did not change him with receiving it as a farthing—I thought it was a

farthing when it was first given—I did not say, "Was not that a farthing you received?"—I saw it on the middle of the counter when she laid it down—he gave her 1/2 lb. of tea, value 2s. 6d. (six ounces and two ounces) and 2lb. of 6d. sugar—the tea was in separate parcels, 6oz. and 2oz., but it was out of the same canister—he put the change on the counter—it was six half-crowns, three shillings, and four pence—she was in the act of taking it up—she had not taken up any part of it—she laid her basket on the counter, and was going to take it up when I interposed.

JOHN UNDERWOOD (policeman.) I took the prisoner in charge—I saw a female at the prisoner's lodging—she appeared before the Magistrate—the prisoner said going to the station that he did not know the female, nor was she his wife—after locking him up, Mr. Lindsey and I went to his lodgings, and inquired if Mr. Griffin lived there, they said "Yes"—we asked if Mr. Griffin was at home, they said "Yes," and called her down.
cross-examined. Q. You had not seen the women before? A. No.
MR. LINDSEY re-examined. I saw her at the lodgings, and we had watched her previously to the lodgings, which we knew were the prisoner's.

GUILTY . Aged 45.—
confined six Months.

1549.
MARY HOLLIDAY was indicted
for stealing 9 towels, value 4s. 6d.; 1 table-cloth, 2s.; 8 pairs of stocking, 1l.; 6 gallons of wine, 4l.; 30 bottles, 5s.; 1 plate, 1 1/2 d.; 1 inkstand, 6d.; 1 pillow-case, 1s.; the goods of
John Spittal Miller, her master.

JOHN SPITTAL MILLER . I live at Camberwell—the prisoner has been in my service as cook about eighteen months. On the 29th of April, in cones
quence of information from Ryan, I looked into my wine-cellar, and missed nearly three dozen of port wine—the wine-cellar was kept locked—nobody ought to have had access to it but myself and my wife, who kept the key—I have since seen the key of my garden-gate, and find it opens the cellar—I was not aware of it before—on the 27th of April I called the prisoner up into my room, charged her with having robbed me of my wine, and said if she would confess what she had done, she might go that night—she denied having robbed me at all, and denied having anything of mine—I called in a police
man and she gave him the keys of her boxes—he searched them, and found a table-cloth, towel, and inkstand, three shell, and other articles, which are my property—no wine was found—she was present when the things were found, and said two or three of them were hers—I identify these towels as my property—they have no mark on them, but I know them—I have been in the habit of seeing them for eighteen months or two years, and consider they are mine—here is one marked "M"—I can swear to that as well as to the others—I do not know that particular mark, but I know it is my towel—I recollect seeing this mark on it before—it is just such a mark as mine had—it is just such an "M" as other persons would have whose names began with "M "—the towels were marked with red—this table-cloth is marked "G. R. M."—that is my brother's mark—I know it was in my possession—this inkstand has no particular mark, but I can swear to it—it was kept in the kitchen—this plate is mine, and this cream-jug—these stocking are my wife's—here is a name on them which I wrote myself—the prisoner's box was locked.
cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. was Jane Ryan in your service?

A. Yes—she came in March last—this charge was made on the 27th of April—I have had a cook in my service since I gave the prisoner in charge—she has left—she did not state that she left in consequence of Ryan's conduct—my wife is not here—she has taken no part in the matter—she has kept aloof from it—she could not identify anything—this word, "Eliza," on the stockings is in my own writing—I did not see them taken from the prisoner's box—all the other articles were—this "M" is not my writing—it might stand for "Mary," as well as for "Miller"—the prisoner said the towels and table-cloth were hers—she did not say the inkstand was hers—she said she took it—I have not the least doubt that the towels and table-cloths are mine—I used the towels to wash with—there is no "M" on them by which I know them, but I swear they are mine—I never heard the prisoner swear they were hers—she said the three marked "M" were hers not the others—the prisoner's box was a pretty large one—I believe she has had a legacy left her lately—there was a small box, with money in it, found in her large box—I believe the legacy is in the savings'-bank—I do not know the amount of it—we had a very good character with her—the inkstand was used in the kitchen by the servants—it was sent down for the purpose—I do not think my wife attended to the making up of the linen for the wash—I cannot say who does—here are three different qualities of towels—my linen is generally marked, but not always—some of these things have been in my possession three or four years—I have not a shadow of a doubt about the towel—I know I took six dozen of port out of my wine-bin in Dec. last—there were thirty-eight remaining—the prisoner had two or three boxes—two were searched in my presence—they contained clothes of various kind—she slept on the second floor, the same floor that I did.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Was the box was stairs? A. Yes, in her own room—I know nothing about the legacy except from what she says.

ADA JANE RYAN . I went into Mr. Miller's service on the 23rd of March—about that day I was in my own room, adjoining the wine-cellar—I heard the wine-cellar door unlocked—I thought it was Mr. Miller—I looked and saw it was the prisoner—I heard her hang the key up in the kitchen—I no
ticed wine in the cupboard some time before that—I dare say there were twenty bottles in a cupboard under the stairs—I mean twenty bottles toge
ther, one following the other—they were sometimes full, and used to be taken away when they were empty—I have seen the empty bottles taken away, and have known them to be the same that I have seen there, by the addition to the number of empty bottles in the garden—they were in rows—I saw bottles in the cupboard when I heard the prisoner come from the cellar—I saw a bottle in the cupboard, there had been about one-third taken out of it—I noticed it again afterwards, and there was about half a pint in it—I did not see it again.

COURT. Q. What made you look at the bottles so frequently? A. I had cause to suspect, having seen bottle there a long time—I thought it was not right, but was not certain where she got it from—I never saw her put them there.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. On the day you saw the bottle there, did you notice anything particular about the prisoner? A. She was under the influence of drink—it was the Thursday week previous to Mr. Miller accusing her—I afterwards looked for the bottle, and saw it with the others in the garden—on the Tuesday morning following, I told Mr. Miller—shortly before this I had to look up some towels for Mr. Miller—they were missing—I came down directly to the prisoner, and said, "Ann, Mr. Miller says there are some towels missing and bid me ask you for them" she said, "I do not know
anything of them"—this was, perhaps, a fortnight or three weeks after she came from the cellar—I saw her take this ink-stand away out of the kitchen.

COURT. Q. Did you ever see her write in her room up stairs? A. Never—I brought these stockings down to her—I put them in the back kitchen, and never saw them again till the policemen found them—the prisoner had there boxes, the box in which the stocking were found was not the prisoner's—she used it for her own purposes—it was an old millinery box—the other things which were found besides those produced were hers.

Cross-examined. Q. When were the stockings found? A. On the morning after she was taken into custody—the box was in a spare room adjoining the kitchen—that was not where we used to throw the things for the wash—the box belonged to Mr. Miller—I found the prisoner's bonnet, and some caps, and a lot of rags, in it—it was not locked—there was no lid to it—I came from Yorkshire to the service of Mr. Fletcher, of Camberwell—it did not suit me, and I gave her warning—I was there a month—after that I went as housekeeper to Mr. Elliott, of grove-lane—he is single, and a man of the highest respectability—I was there two months—I was too young for the situation, and did not like to live with him alone—I was not exactly cook enough for him—Mr. Rockwell, whom I lived with three years and a half, brought me from Yorkshire—I have been in no situations in London but what I have named—the cook who came to Mr. Miller's after the prisoner, has gone away—Mr. Miller did not keep the key of the cupboard under the stairs—there was no key to it—I sometimes
