had occasion to go to it—I never tasted the wine—I am quite sure it was wine—I held it up to the light, and took the cork out to smell it—I am certain I did not taste it—there is a pretty good deal of wine drank in the house—the bottles go into the garden when done with—there is a heap there in rows—I used to count the bottles after my suspicions arose—this was the first time I saw where the prisoner got the wine from—I heard her speak of opening other apartments with keys of her own, and I tried the key to the cellar—I did not try any other apartment—I saw a fresh bottle on Saturday, and one on Sunday—there was only one at a time—I know it was a different bottle each time—my mistress superintends the house—I took up the linen for the wash—the dirty linen is always kept down stairs, in a large bin—it is not taken up to Mr. Miller, and counted out regularly—Mr. Miller never sends a servant to the wine-cellar—I never saw the prisoner drink a glass of wine—I was not much with her—I was very frequently up stairs, or out with the children.

EDMUND DAY (police-constable P 155.) On Friday evening I was called to Mr. Miller's house, and I asked the prisoner about her boxes—she showed me two, and gave me the keys—I opened them, and found these towels, stockings, and plate—the stockings were in a little wooden box, in the same room when I found them, but they were placed away in another room—the articles in both boxes were intermixed—the first two were locked—I opened them with the keys she gave me—I found all the things in them, except the stockings—it was a small wooden box which was left in the room—I did not examine it particularly that evening—there appeared to be dusters or house-cloths in it, and a bonnet, I think—I examined it more par
ticularly next morning, and found eight pairs of stockings pinned up in an old dirty silk handkerchief—it was then up stairs in the prisoner's room—it had been taken up there by Ryan.

Cross-examined. Q. Did she give you the keys at once when you asked for them? A. Yes—she said the towels were hers—this milk-pot is produced to match with the plate, it is not charged to be stolen—the ink-stand was in her box—I looked at the other box carelessly, and did not see the stockings—it
was in her room that night—it had been brought up there by me and her fellow-servant—next morning when I came I found the stockings in it.

ADA JANE RYAN
re-examined. The towels and other were kept in Mr. Miller's wardrobe, but these had not been used by the family while I had been there, which is three months.

COURT. Q. When did you first mention seeing the bottles secreted? A. On the Tuesday previous to Mr. Miller's accusing her—it was on the Thurs
day before that I found her at the cellar—I was afraid to mention it before, as she had been there longer than I had.

JURY. Q. How long is it since the first of the twenty bottles was seen in the cupboard? A. The first I saw was when I had been in the house about a week, the next a few days, after, and the third a few days after that—a bot
tle lasted in the cupboard about three days—we have a shilling a week allowed for beer money, and I thought she might have bought it out of that—I am away from the kitchen so much that I could not watch where she got the wine from.
NOT GUILTY .

1550.
HENRY SMYRKE was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles Clarke and another, at St. Mary, Newington, and stealing therein 2 shawls, value 3l. 13s.; 1 half-shawl, 1l.; 24 handkerchiefs, 3l.; 8 neckkerchiefs, 1l. 10s.; 3 scarfs, 13s.; and 637 yards of silk, 60l. 7s.; their property.

JAMES WICKENS . I am carman to Chaplin and Home, and live in Corn
bury-street, Old Kent-road. On the 3rd of May, about a quarter-past six o'clock in the morning, I saw two men walking backwards and forwards in the Dover-road, close to Mr. Clarke's shop—one of them took off his top coat, hung it before his legs, and close by the area grating—the other one came behind him, lifted up the grating, and somebody from below put out a large sack—the one who lifted it up put it on his shoulder, and walked towards Napier-street—the prisoner was not one of those men—he was about fifteen yards from the place with a cab—he saw the men coming with the bag, opened the cab-door, and the person who had it put it into the cab—I informed the police—I had seen the cab standing there for about five minutes—the prisoner could see what they were doing, if he was looking.

Prisoner. You stated before the Magistrate that I was half-way down Napier-street. A. I said your cab was a little way down the street—I do not know the length of Napier-street—I believe you were fifteen yards off Napier-street—I was about 11 yards from the shop, and you were about two yards down the street.

WILLIAM RANDALL (policeman.) On the morning of the 15th April I received information, went towards Napier-street, and saw a cab which the prisoner was driving towards Kent-street—I saw a man running alongside the cab—I called to the cab-man to stop—I was in my police dress—he was near enough to hear me, but drove on—the man by the side of the cab went off in another direction—I followed the cab, stopped it in Long-lane, and asked the prisoner what he had got—he said he did not know—I asked where he had got it from—he said it was put into the cab in Napier-street—I asked by whom—he said by two men who employed him in Aldersgate-street—I took him to the station, and found the property stated, in the cab—I produce it—Napier-street is about twenty yards from Mr. Clark's shop—there are four houses in Napier-street.

Prisoner. Q. When you stopped me was not I a long way down Long-lane? A. Yes; I did not stop you myself, you pulled up—when I asked where you got it from, you said two gentlemen put it into the cab at the corner of Napier-street—I did not ask what you were going to do with it—I got on the cab, and you drove on—you made no resistance.

JAMES WILES WHIBLEY . I am an assistant to Charles Clarke, a draper, in the Dover-road. On Thursday morning I went to the station and found these goods, I know them to be my employer's—I had locked the premises the night before, about half-past nine o'clock, and went away—I did not sleep there—next morning I was called up by one of the young men, and found the shop had been entered by the grating window, through the area, the silk all taken off the rollers, and the shawl drawer open—the maid-servant had been in the shop before me—she lives in the house—she is not here.

Prisoner's Defence. Two gentlemen ordered me over the water, and told me to wait in Napier-street till they came to me; they brought a cab, and told me to drive over to Bermondsey Church, and took my number at the same time; I drove off, and when the policeman called me I stopped—a per
son two yards off cannot see the house.

WILLIAM RANDALL
re-examined. I can see the house twelve yards up thestreet.

JAMES WICKENS
re-examined. I could see the house and the grating fromwhere the cab stood—when I saw the prisoner I was in the Dover-road.
NOT GUILTY .

1551.
FREDERICK HAGGETT was indicted
for feloniously breakingand entering the shop of
Richard Waygood, at St. Mary, Newington, and stealing 5 metal taps, value 15s.; and two copper boilers, 30s.; his property.

RICHARD WAYGOOD . I live in the Blackfriars-road, and have a shop at Newington-causeway. I have a back entrance leading to Tibberton-street—when you go in there you come into a yard, and another door leads into theshop—I know the doors were all locked up at eight o'clock the evening pre
vious—both the gates were locked, one comes into the yard, and one into the shop—I went to the shop about six o'clock on Saturday morning and found the front door broken open—I afterwards examined the back door, which was forced open—I missed two large copper boilers and a lot of brass taps which I had seen safe the night before—I have not seen them since—I should know them again—I sent a fac-simile of the coppers to the police—the prisoner worked for me about twelve months at the manufactory.

WILLIAM BOSTICK . I am an engineer, and live in Tibberton-street—I work in the next premises to the prosecutor. On the 9th of April I left my premises about ten minutes after eight at night—I know the back gates which Mr. Waygood speaks of—I locked them that night—we both have access to the yard—I took the keys with me—I went next morning at a quarter to six; found the box of the lock wrenched back, and the wicket gate open.

CHARLES WATERS (policeman.) On the 10th of April, about twenty minutes to six in the morning, I was in William-street, about 150 yards from the prosecutor's premises, and saw the prisoner coming in a direction from there with a copper boiler under his arm, similar to the one produced—I noticed the peculiarity of it, and heard something ratling inside it—I thought he was going to his work, and did not stop him.

WILLIAM DAVIS (policeman.) On the morning of the 10th of April I saw the prisoner in St. Ann's-road, carrying a boiler similar to the one pro
duced, and he had a bag and something in it.

RICHARD WAYGOOD
re-examined. The copper produced is like the one I lost.

JURY. Q. Does anybody else make such boilers? A. Not to my know
jedge.
WILLIAM HARDEN . I saw the prisoner outside the prosecutor's premises, from half-past five to six o'clock.
NOT GUILTY .

1552.
FREDERICK HAGGETT was again indicted
for obtaining from
William pain 6 lbs. weight of lamb, value 5s. 6d.; and a 1/2 lb. weight of snet, 4d.; by false pretences; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1553.
JAMES COLLINS was indicted
for a rape on
Ada Gammon the younger, a girl aged about 7 years of age; on the 6th of may.
NOT GUILTY .

1544.
JAMES COLLINS was again indicted
for rape on the said
Ada Gammon, on the 28th of May.
MR. ROBINSON offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1555.
WILLIAM TURNER was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of May, 1 coat, value 2s.; the goods of
William Tarrant ; also,
on the 19th of May, 1 coat, value 2s. the goods of
William Tarrant; and that he had been before convicted of felony, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined One Year.
